docs.text: Meaning Script Analysis IPA I see a cat. ཀོཁིཡ་ཨོཡིཕ། I+cat see You are a bear. པིཟྲོམ་དྲི། You+bear be We want to eat. ཀཕོཙིདས་ནིདྶ། We+eat want I want to eat food. ཙིག་ཀོཙིདས་ནིདྶ། food I+eat want I don't want a cat. ཀོཁིཡ་ཡོུ་ནིདྶ། I+cat neg want I don't like spicy food. ཀོཕྩོགརིཇྯེ་ཡོུ་ཤེཆ། I+bare+food+adj+spicy neg enjoy I'm happy when you're happy. པིཐེུལརིསལེ་ཀོདྲིརོསལེ་དྲི། You+you+adj+happy I+be+adv+happy be Cats are sometimes big. ཀེུཕྑིཡརིཧོརོཅྷིགྲད་དྲི། gp+bare+cat+adj+big+adv+sometimes be The cats eat the food. ཡྑིཡྠཀེུཡྩིག་ཙིདས། Def+cat+pl+gp+def+food eat The big happy cat is here. ཀེུཡྑིཡརིཧོསལེརོངོབ་དྲི། gp+def+cat+adj+big+happy+adv+here be [biməŋamhaɹ̠usnihujut k'a] I want her to want you to eat food. པིཙིག་ཛིཙིདས་ཀོནིདྶ་ནིདྶ you+bare+food her+eat i+want want Meaning Script Analysis The big, happy cats eat the food. ཡྑིཡྠཀེུཡྩིགརེུཧོསལེ་ནིདྶ། def+cat+pl+gp+def+food+subadj+big+happy eat We give the books on the table to you and to them. you list them table on we+def+book+pl givek I often see the dog in the house on the hill. def+hill on def+house in i+def+dog+adv+frequent see The food is in the house and on the table in summer. def+food+gp+def+house in list def+table on summer in be The red and big cats are here and happy. gp+def+cat+pl+adj+red+big+adv+here+happy be The man gives the child a book and a bag in the market. def+child book list bag def+man+gp+market in give You and I eat fish with rice and with beans together. rice with list beans with i+list+you+gp+fish eat We speak about the food on the table and in the house. table on list house in we+def+food speak

docs.text: Possession Possession is marked in two different ways depending on if it is alienable or inalienable. Inalienable Inalienable possession is marked by compounding the words with the connector སཉི [sqa]. Example: "The man's child": ཡྷོབིུསཉིཔེཔེ (DEF+man+POSS+child) Alienable Alienable possession is marked by the particle སྙི [səqa], placed before the object that is being possessed. If the subject of the clause is the possessed object, then possession is marked by putting the particle before the verb instead. Examples: I see the man's cat: ཡྷོབིུ་སྙི་ཀོཁིཡ Word order hierarchy direct object -> indirect object -> dummy, obliques are complicated If there’s nothing of the form higher in the hierarchy, attach to the next thing that does exist. If nothing exists use the dummy. Word order for subject object: General word order follows the hierarchy, where “verb” is at the top and you go to the left from there Subject attaches right before verb except when the list particle is involved OTHER IDEA: Subject word order is free. Before the verb is maybe the "default" if you're not really thinking about it. But subject acts as a light 'topic marker' List particle: means “the next word is another in the same level, not a step up” maybe also a particle for each jump in the hierarchy, except the “last direct object to verb” jump which is unmarked. Then placement in the hierarchy need not be marked (indirect object + verb would just have the “indirect object jump” particle before the verb) If the subject is a bare pronoun, use the reflexive pronoun objects and double up. Otherwise, use dummy pronoun + the normal object. The first way might be considered something that is falling out of use and it’d be understood if you always did it the second way Particles for ”on”, “around”, etc: go between the words they act on, unless there’s a list particle in between: Examples: I eat the food on the table: “table on i+food eat The food is on the table in the house “Table on house in dummy+food be” The food is on the table and in the house “Table on list house in dummy+food be” Relative particle comes before relative clause, which comes before the host. Clause end is unambiguous as verbs end clauses. Has two forms for if its talking about a subject or an object Relative object and subject are all you need (2 words only) Descriptives After the main subject-object body of a word come a series of suffixes called "descriptives". Although roots are very often either primarily descriptive roots or primarily noun roots, which one they are in a given word is determined by their placement rather than their sound. The category of descriptive is known by the descriptive marker that precedes it. The marker does not need to immediately precede it: instead, the marker applies to all following descriptives until the next marker is used. There are three descriptive markers: 1. The adjectival descriptive marker རི [ha]. This marker tell you that the descriptives that follow it modify the object to which the marker is attached. 2. The adverbal descriptive marker རོ [hu]. This marker tell you that the descriptives that follow it modify the verb of the clause of which the attached object is an object. Depending on the descriptor, it also can make it modify the event described by the clause in general. It is typically applied only to objects that directly precede the verb, or to the direct object of the verb, though it can in principle be marked on any object. 3. The subject adjectival descriptive marker རིུ [hĩ]. This marker tells you that the descriptives that follow it modify the subject of the clause of which the attached object is an object. It is, almost as a rule, applied only to objects with attached subjects.

docs.text: Orthography The (computer-friendly) standard orthography is written using the Tibetan Script , although all sound values have been reassigned without reference to the sounds they make in existing Tibetic languages, so knowing such a language will not help you read it. Vowels Script Sound ཨི a ཨིུ ã ཨེ i ཨེུ ĩ ཨོ u ཨོུ ũ Explained later ə As in typical use of Tibetan script, vowels are marked with diacritics, making this writing system an abugida. Unlike in typical Indic scripts, lack of a vowel diacritic does not imply any specific vowel, and in fact all vowels are marked by diacritics. Like in Tibetan, the letter ཨ marks a lack of a consonant and is used in words that begin with a vowel. Consonants Bilabial / Labiodental Script Sound ག p གྲ pʼ ཀ b ཆ f ཚ v Alveolar Script Sound བ t བྲ tʼ པ d ས s མ z ཇ t͡s ཛ d͡z Retroflex / Palatal Script Sound ཅ ʈ ཙ ɖ ཤ tɕ ཐ ɕ སྲ ʂ མྲ ʐ Velar Script Sound ད k དྲ kʼ ཏ g ཁ ŋ Uvular Script Sound ཉ q ཉྲ qʼ ན ɢ ཝ ʁ Liquids & Sonorants Script Sound ཡ m ལ n ཕྲ r ཟྲ ɽ͡r̥ ཟ r̥ ཕ ɾ ཧ ɹ̠ ང j Glottal / Laryngeal Script Sound ར h Note that certain consonants (in particular, the phonemes /p’/, /t’/, /k’/, /q’/, /ʂ/, /ʐ/, /r/, and /ɽ͡r̥/) are written using a base letter with a subjoined ར. These eight consonants are referred to here as "marked" consonants. Stacking If you are familiar with the Tibetan script, you will know of "stacking," the convention of placing letters on top of one another to form consonant clusters. Stacking is used here as well, but with a different function. Because this orthography has no inherent vowel, consonant clusters can be written simply by placing characters side by side. When one consonant is stacked beneath another, however, it signals the presence of an implicit schwa [ə] between them. In this way, the writing system allows clusters that might otherwise be unpronounceable to appear in orthography. This example illustrates the difference: - སདི = [ska] - སྡི = [səka] Marked consonants (those written with subjoined ར) are not permitted in stacks due to their orthographic formation. When marked consonants occur in normal consonant clusters, an implicit schwa is automatically inserted to make the cluster pronounceable. The only exception is the voiced alveolar trill /r/, which occurs in certain consonant clusters without an implicit schwa. Additionally, the consonant ར (h) cannot appear in subjoined position. Transliteration When a word (say, a proper name) is transliterated into the language, the word is marked in the orthography with a ཨཻ mark on the first character. Examples ཉྲསེ → [qʼəsi] ཐྶིུཡྑ → [ɕəsĩməŋ] བྨོལ → [təzun] པཕྲིད → [drak] སྡིཝྒབྶེཕྡཏྭོསྲཁ → [səkaʁəp.təsiɾək.gəʁuʂəŋ] ཨིཻལབླེ → [antəni] (Anthony)
docs.title: Orthography

docs.text: Phonotactics Syllable Structure The basic syllable structure is (C)(C)V(C)(C). Consonant clusters may appear both in onset and coda positions, but are subject to many restrictions described below. The vowel /ə/ functions differently from the full vowels /a, i, u/. It is best understood as an epenthetic vowel: it surfaces in clusters that would otherwise be extremely difficult or impossible, particularly in stacked (orthographic) consonants. For this reason, the structure can alternatively be analyzed as (C)(ə)(C)V(C)(ə)(C), where schwa may intervene to “rescue” clusters without acting as a full vowel of its own. While all consonants are allowed as onsets, only certain consonants are allowed as singleton codas. In particular, the following list of consonants are disallowed as singleton codas: - The ejectives: [p'], [t'], [k'], [q'] - The retroflex stops and fricatives: [ʈ], [ɖ], [ʂ], [ʐ] - The glottal fricative: [h] - The uvular stops: [q], [ɢ] - The palatal affricate: [tɕ] Consonant Clusters Orthographically, two mechanisms exist: 1. True clusters , written as adjacent consonants. 2. Schwa-clusters , normally written with stacking, where a schwa is inserted between consonants. Generally, schwa-clusters are far less restrictive than true clusters. True Clusters As noted in the orthography section, marked consonants, excluding /r/, do not appear at all in true clusters. These consist of the ejectives, the retroflex fricatives, and the retroflex trill. Onsets The following structural types are permitted: - Fricative + stop: སབ [st], སག [sp], ཐཔ [ɕd] - The labiodental fricatives [f] and [v] are not allowed in this type of cluster. - Uvular stops are generally disallowed in this type of cluster, with the exception of སཉ [sq]. - Clusters with voiced fricatives in the initial position are generally excluded. - Retroflex stops are excluded. - Stop + rhotic: ཏཕྲ [gr], ཀཝ [bʁ], ཐཕ [dɾ] - Uvular stops ([q],[ɢ]) do not occur in this cluster type. - Retroflex stops are excluded. - Fricative + nasal: མལ [zn], སཁ [sŋ], ཐཡ [ɕm] - The labiodental fricatives [f] and [v] are not allowed in this type of cluster. - Fricative + rhotic: ཆཟ [fr̥], སཝ [sʁ], མཕ [zɾ] - The labiodental fricative [v] is not allowed in this type of cluster. - The voiceless alveolar trill [r̥] is not allowed after a voiced consonant. Codas Anything that is not permitted as a singleton coda cannot appear at the end of a coda cluster. The following structural types are permitted: - Stop + fricative: དས [ks], ཏམ [gz], གས [ps] - [ɕ] does not appear in this type of cluster. - Nasal + stop: ལབ [nt], ལཔ [nd], ཁཏ [ŋg] - Retroflex stops are excluded. - Rhotic + stop: ཟབ [rt], ཝག [ʁp], ཕཔ [ɾd] - The voiceless alveolar rhotic must be followed by a voiceless stop. Schwa Clusters Schwa clusters are extremely loose. The following are the only general restrictions on what might appear in one: A schwa-cluster in the coda of a syllable cannot end with a consonant that is disallowed as a singleton coda. A cluster consisting of two identical consonants. A cluster consisting of two uvular consonants. A cluster consisting of a consonant and its voiced/voiceless pair. A cluster consisting of two retroflex consonants. A cluster consisting of two trills. A cluster consisting of two ejectives. A cluster ending in [h].
docs.title: Phonotactics

docs.text: Object Pronouns Person Script IPA 1sg ཅིཡ [ʈam] 2sg ཐེལ [ɕin] 3sg ཁིད [ŋak] 1pl ཅིསྱ [ʈasəm] 2pl ཐེབླ [ɕitən] 3pl ཁིམྲད [ŋaʐək] relative མྲོཏ [ʐug] ## Dummy Object Pronouns Dummy object pronouns are formed by nasalizing the vowel of the corresponding plain object pronoun. They are used as object-slot fillers for intransitive verbs. Person Script IPA 1sg ཅིུཡ [ʈãm] 2sg ཐེུལ [ɕĩn] 3sg ཁིུད [ŋãk] 1pl ཅིུསྱ [ʈãsəm] 2pl ཐེུབླ [ɕĩtən] 3pl ཁིུམྲད [ŋãʐək] ## Verbs Verb Script IPA --------------------------------------- ---------- ------------- go / take to ཆི [fa] be དྲི [k'a] see ཨོཡིཕ [u.maɾ] eat ཙིདས [ɖaks] drink ཇིུཆ [t͡sãf] want ནིདྶ [ɢakəs] like / enjoy ཤེཆ [tɕif] force/burst ཉིཔྱ [qadəm] burst in / enter forcefully ཙྙིཔྱ [ɖəqadəm] resemble / be seen ཏྴོཡིཕ [gətɕu.maɾ] walk ཆིཇ [fat͡s] turn ཆིམིཆ [fa.zaf] turn over / flip ཏོུཆྨིཆ [gũfzaf] flip aggressively ཏོུཆྙིཔྱ [gũfəqadəm] create/produce/have (a child) སེུཡེམ [sĩmiz] say ནོག [ɢup] carry / hold / bear ཟོམ [r̥uz] to cause (X) / to transform (X to Y) ཨིུཡི [ãma] to inhabit ཨིནིཔ [aɢad] to work / labor བྲོཡྶ [t'uməs] to give ཡྴིལྡ [mətɕanək] to meet (planned) ཨོཡོུབ [umũt] to encounter to rise / to ascend / to grow ཆྟོུང [fəgũj] to put / to place ཨེཟ [ir̥] to plant / to sow མྲབེཟ [ʐətir̥] to continue བྲོུསྱ [t'ũsəm] to do some action / placeholder(?) verb ངེཕ [jiɾ] to know (factual) གེསོུ [pisũ] to uproot ཡིུམབྯིུཡི [mãztr̥ãma] to shine སིཡེཕྲ [samir] to help གྶིཆ [pəsaf] to agree ནིུརྒ [ɢãhəp] to listen ཝོཟབ [ʁurt] to excel / be good at ཚིཚེས [vavis] to think ཀཕྲིཉོུ [braqũ] to bloom / to thrive ཆྟེཟ [fəgir̥] ## Pronoun Affixes Person Script IPA ----------------- ------ -------- 1sg ཀོ [bu] 2sg པི [da] 3sg ཛི [d͡za] 1pl ཀཕོ [bɾu] 2pl པཕི [dɾa] 3pl ཇེ [t͡si] post-object/dummy ཀེུ [bĩ] topic mark བ [t] relative ཆཝོ [fʁu] Misc. Affixes Affix Script IPA Type adjectival རི [ha] suffix adverbal རོ [hu] suffix subject adjectival རེུ [hĩ] suffix definiteness ཡ(ཡི) [m]([ma]) prefix plural ཐ(ཨེུཐ) [ɕ]([ĩɕ]) suffix bare ཕ(ཕེ) [ɾ]([ɾi]) prefix kind/type ཝིུ [ʁã] prefix superlative སཁི [sŋa] up suffix passivization (verbs) ཏྴི [gətɕa] (sometimes [tɕa]) prefix comparative སཁོ [snu] suffix "to cause to X" ཨིུཡ [ãm] prefix adjectivization (-ing, as an adjective, for verbs) ཛྱ(ཨིཛྱ) [ad͡zəm] suffix ## Connectors Connector Script IPA ------------------------ ------ ------- possession (inalienable) སཉི [sqa] and (list) ངེ [ji] -'s house བེཧ [tiɹ̠] -named ཡེ [mi] ## Noun roots Noun Script IPA ------------------------------------------------------- ---------- --------------- cat ཁིཡ [ŋam] dog ཉྲིབ [q'at] bear ཟྲོམ [ɽ͡r̥uz] binturong ཟྲོམྑིཡ [ɽ͡r̥u.zəŋam] food ཙིག [ɖap] time གྲོད [p'uk] painting depiction thing སྲིུ [ʂã] this (obj) ངོསྲིུ [juʂã] that (obj) ཀྔོསྲིུ [bəjuʂã] light ཆེཕྲ [fir] fire ཆོུཝ [fũʁ] -similar ཚིལ [van] illumination ཡོུབྲིཆེཕྲ [mũt'afir] square/plaza གིུངམེ [pãj.zi] center དེཡླ [kimən] shaft/rod/stick ཀཕྲིུཝ [brãʁ] stone ཅེག [ʈip] tree ཟྲསིུས [ɽ͡r̥əsãs] pillar ཅེགསིས [ʈipsas] load/haul བྲོཡ [t'um] fog ཐེཝ [ɕiʁ] foot ཉིུཇ [qãt͡s] log དྲིཕྲ [k'ar] wood (material) དྲིསྲིཕྲ [k'aʂar] up ཏོུང [gũj] down ཟེག [r̥ip] person ཧོཔི [ɹ̠uda] child པེཔེ [didi] mom ཡིུཡིུ [mãmã] dad བིབིུ [tatã] attitude / disposition དྲེཡེཟ [k'imir̥] car (automobile) ཆིཆིཟྲ [fafaɽ͡r̥] house ནྦེཧ [ɢətiɹ̠] place བེཧ [tiɹ̠] fish ཐཡེ [ɕmi] market ཚྶིཕྲལ [vəsarən] day ཉེས [qis] today ཉེརྦ [qihət] work (the daily grind) བྲོཡསཉེརྦ [t'umsqihət] man ཧོབིུ [ɹ̠utã] woman ཧོཡིུ [ɹ̠umã] gift ཡྴེསྲིུ [mətɕiʂã] sun མོཀ [zub] carrot ངིཕྲམ [jarəz] seed / egg མྲེཡ [ʐim] origin མྲེཅྱ [ʐiʈəm] boy བིུཔེ [tãdi] girl ཡིུཔེ [mãdi] luck / chance ཇོཇ [t͡sut͡s] sibling ཀིངིཁ [bajaŋ] brother བིུངིཁ [tãjaŋ] sister ཡིུངིཁ [mãjaŋ] everyone ཧྦོཟྲད [ɹ̠əduɽ͡r̥ək] plant ཛྐེཀ [d͡zəbib] kudzu དོཻཛོ [kud͡zu] weed དྫོ [kəd͡zu] water ཉྲིུ [q'ã] ground ཟྲོུཀླ [ɽ͡r̥ũbən] tomorrow ཉེཅིུརྦ [qitãhət] mountain ཆིཟྲ [faɽ͡r̥] summit ཏྔིཟྲ [gəjaɽ͡r̥] the world, the earth ཟྲོབི [ɽ͡r̥uta] nature ཕྲམིབ [rəzat] forest / woods ཡོསིུཅྶ [musãʈəs] location / space མྲེབི [ʐita] group ཧོུཡོད [rũmuk] acquaintance / non-stranger with a friedly relationship བྴོཔི [tətɕuda] community བྴོཡོད [tətɕumuk] friend group of friends speech ནྒི [ɢəpa] ## Particles Particle Script IPA -------------------------------------------------- ------ ------------------------------------ negation ཡོུ [mũ] list ངེ [ji] indirect ཝི [ʁa] possession (alienable) སྙི [səqa] (often [sqa] in practice) and also (clause connector) ཚིུཧ [vãɹ̠] with (using) སྲལོུ [ʂənũ] in / at (general, not necessarily "inside") ཙི [ɖa] then (clause connector) ཡླི [məni] over ཙྟ྄ོ [ɖəgũ] under ཙྯེ [ɖər̥i] with (containing), used for quotes ཏཟོ [gɾu] because of (choice) / inspired by སལོུཤི [snũtɕa] for (purpose) on condition of མེ [zi] after གྲོུཙྟ [p'ũɖəg] before གྲོུཙྯ [p'ũɖər̥] adjacent ཛེལ [d͡zin] relative clause starter རིཡ [ham] at the time of གྲེ [p'i] future tense རིུ [hã] however / but ཆིམ [faz] in the same way as མྱེུཐ [zəmĩɕ] near / around ཛེལཔ [d͡zind] including (similar to containing, less "physical") ཏཕྲོས [grus] "located in", ephasis more on location མྲེུཙི [ʐĩɖa] particle to act as event modifier for obliques ཀིུལ [bãn] ## Adjectives Adjective Script IPA --------------------------- -------- --------------- --- big ཧོ [ɹ̠u] spicy ཇྯེ [t͡sər̥i] happy སལེ [sni] sometimes ཅྷིགྲད [ʈəɹ̠ap'ək] here ངོབ [jut] there ཀྔོབ [bəjut] dark གབྲོ [pət'u] important ཧྡོཡྶ [ɹ̠əkumən] good bright སཡེཕྲ [smir] solid ཅེཚིལ [ʈivan] heavy བྲོཡིལ [t'uman] powerful ཟྲོཚིལ [ɽ͡r̥uvan] small པེ [di] open ཀོུཁ [bũŋ] bad གྲི [p'a] hot cold frequent གྲོཡོད [p'umuk] difficult ཀིགབྲོ [bapt'u] easy abstract / strange རྣིཧ [həɢaɹ̠] adjacent ཛེུལ [d͡zĩn] repeated / again གྲིསཁོ [p'asnu] unfortunate old གྷོ [pəɹ̠u] young གྤོ [pədu] older (sibling) གྷོས [pəɹ̠us] younger (sibling) གྤོས [pədus] planted / rooted / in place མེབྯ [ʐitər̥] wet ཉྲིུང [q'ãj] inclusive ཏཕྲོསྦེཕ [grusətiɾ] competent / excellent ཚིཚེཕ [vaviɾ] thriving ancient/historical ཧོཟྲསཚིལ [ɹ̠uɽ͡r̥əsvan] cutting-edge new ## Numbers Number Script IPA Numeral zero ཨོལ [un] ༅ one ཡོུབ [mũt] ཞ two ཝིུཏ [ʁãg] ཞྱ three ཡེམ [miz] རྮ four བྲིཆ [t'af] རྮྲ five མྲིཧ [ʐaɹ̠] རྮྱ six ཨེཁ [iŋ] ཞ༅ thirty six ཨོུང [ũj] ཞ༅༅ fifty ཡོུབོུངཝིུཏེཁཝིུཏ [mũtũjʁãgiŋʁãg] ཞཞྱཞྱ one hundred ཝིུཏོངབྲིཆེཁབྲིཆ [ʁãgũjt'afiŋt'af] ཞྱརྮྲརྮྲ ## Counters Counter Script IPA some (specifying that you don’t know how much) ཅྷི [ʈəɹ̠a] every ཟྲིད [ɽ͡r̥ak] many ཡོཡོད [mumuk] acre སིཻདྥ [akəɾ] ## Phrases Counter Script IPA --------------------- ------------------- ------------------------- "Once upon a time..." གྲོདརིཧྡོཡྶཨེུཐཅྷི། [p'ukhaɹ̠əkumənĩɕʈəɹ̠a,] "One day" / "Once" གྲོདརི། [p'ukha] ## Time words Word Script IPA ---- ------ ------- now རེཟ [hir̥] ## Transliterations Word Script IPA --------- -------- ---------- Cambridge དིཻཡཀཕེཐ [kambɾiɕ] Girton ཏེཻཕབླ [giɾtən] Anthony ཨིཻལབླེ [antəni] Trinity བཻཕེལྦེ [tɾinəti]

docs.text: Original Script IPA Gloss I see a dog. ཀོཉྲིབ་ཨོཡིཕ༎ [buq'at umaɾ] 1SG-dog see You are walking to the market. ཡིཚྶིཕྲལ་པིཐེུལ་ཆིཇ༎ [mavəsarən daɕĩn fat͡s] DEF-market 2SG-2SG.INTR walk They often eat together after work. ཇེཁིུམྲདརོཡོུབངེགྲོཡོད་བྲོཡསཉེརྦ་གྲོུཙྟ་ཙིདས༎ [t͡siŋãʐəkhamũtjip'umuk t'umsqihət p'ũɖəg ɖaks] 3PL-3PL.INTR-ADV-one-AND-frequent workday after eat We will meet again when the sun rises. ཀཕོཅིུསྱརོགྲིསཁོ་ཀེུམོཀ་ཆྟོུང་གྲེ་རིུ་ཨོཡོུབ༎ [bɾuʈãsəmhup'asnu bĩzub fəgũj p'i hã umũt] 1PL-1PL.INTR-ADV-repeated EXPL.SBJ-sun rise time future meet The man who lives next door gave me a strange gift. ཅིཡ་རིཡ་ཡིནྦེཧ་ཛེལ་ཆཝོབམྲོཏ་ཨིནིཔ་ཧོབིུཀེུཡྴེསྲིུརིརྣིཧ་ཡྴིལྡ༎ [ʈam ham maɢətiɹ̠ d͡zin fʁutʐug aɢad ɹ̠utãbĩmətɕiʂãhahəɢaɹ̠ mətɕanək] 1SG REL DEF-house adjacent REL.SBJ-REL.OBJ reside man-EXPL.SBJ-gift-ADJ-weird give I wanted to help her, but she refused to listen. ཁིད་གྶིཆོཀ་ནིདྶ།ཆིམ་ཝོཟབིས་ཡོུ་ནིུརྒ༎ [ŋak pəsafub ɢakəs faz ʁurtas mũ ɢãhəp] 3SG help-1SG.PST want but listen-3SG.PST NEG agree Even though the storm had ended, the streets were still flooded. If I had spoken more carefully, they might have understood my meaning. The book that you said your sister wanted to borrow has already been returned. Should they decide to leave before dawn, we will have no choice but to follow. Knowledge without wisdom is like a tree without roots: it grows, but it cannot stand. Despite centuries of conflict and countless broken promises, humanity continues its relentless pursuit of harmony, as if driven by an unquenchable longing for something it has never truly known.

docs.text: གྲོདརི།ཅིུཡོཀ་ཆིཇ་ཡླི་དྲིཕྲོཀརིཧོ་ཨོཡིཕ༎ ཡླི་ཡདྲིཕྲོཀ་ཏོུཆྨིཆ།ཀཕྲིུཝསྲིརིཔེཔེ་ཁིད་ཙྯེ་དྲི༎ ཿཔེཔེསྲིཡདྲིཕྲརེུཀྔོབ་སེུཡེམ༑ཿཏཕོ་སྲིུསྲོཀ་ནོག༎ One day, I was walking, and I saw this big log. Then, I rolled the log over and underneath was a tiny little stick. And I was like, “That log had a child!“ Original Script IPA Gloss One day, I was walking, and I saw this big log. གྲོདརི།ཅིུཡོཀ་ཆིཇ་ཡླི་དྲིཕྲོཀརིཧོ་ཨོཡིཕ༎ [p'ukha, ʈãmub fat͡s məni k'arubhaɹ̠u umaɾ] time-ADJ 1SG-1SG.PST walk then log-1SG.PST-ADJ-BIG see Then, I rolled the log over and underneath was a tiny little stick. ཡླི་ཡདྲིཕྲོཀ་ཏོུཆྨིཆ།ཀཕྲིུཝསྲིརིཔེཔེ་ཁིད་ཙྯེ་དྲི༎ [məni mək'arub gũfzaf, brãʁʂahadidi ŋak ɖər̥i k'a] then DEF-log-1SG.PST upturn / stick-EXPL.SBJ.PST-ADJ-SMALL-REDUP 3SG BELOW be And I was like, “That log had a child!“ ཿཔེཔེསྲིཡདྲིཕྲརེུཀྔོབ་སེུཡེམ༑ཿཏཕོ་སྲིུསྲོཀ་ནོག༎ [didiʂamək'arhĩbəjut sĩmiz gɾu ʂãʂub ɢup] child-EXPL.SBJ.PST-DEF-log-SBJ.ATTR-THERE create CONT(QUOT) thing-1SG.PST say
docs.title: Big Log Story

docs.text: At the frontier of inclusive excellence, set in 50 acres of natural woodlands, orchards and wildlife habitats, Girton offers space to think and a community in which to thrive. Live in heritage buildings or state of the art accommodation, enjoy the Library, Cafe and indoor swimming pool, and some of the best on-site sporting and leisure facilities in the University. [vaviɾhagrusətiɾ sqa gəjaɽ͡r̥ ɖa] ཚིཚེཕརིཏཕྲོསྦེཕ་སྙི་ཏྔིཟྲ་ཙི་ངེ་ཡོསིུཅྶེུཐསིཻདྥེཐཞཞྱཞྱརིཕྲམིབཚིལ་མྲེུཙི་ཀིུལ།ཏེཻཕབླཀེུམྲེབིརིཀཕྲིཉོུ་ངེ་བྴོཡོདརིཆྟེཟ་ཡྴིལྡ༎ [vaviɾhagrusətiɾ sqa gəjaɽ͡r̥ ɖa ji musãʈəsĩɕakəɾĩɕmũtũjʁãgiŋʁãgharəzatvan ʐĩɖa bãn giɾtənbĩʐitahabraqũ ji tətɕumukhafəgir̥ mətɕanək] excellent+ADJ+inclusive POSS summit at AND woodlands+PL+acre+PL+50+ADJ+natural in BAN Girton+EXPL.SBJ+space+ADJ+think AND community+ADJ+thrive give Original Script IPA Gloss At the frontier of inclusive excellence, set in 50 acres of natural woodlands, orchards and wildlife habitats, Girton offers space to think and a community in which to thrive. ཚིཚེཕརིཏཕྲོསྦེཕ་སྙི་ཏྔིཟྲ་ཙི་ངེ་ཡོསིུཅྶེུཐསིཻདྥེཐཞཞྱཞྱརིཕྲམིབཚིལ་མྲེུཙི་ཀིུལ།ཏེཻཕབླཀེུམྲེབིརིཀཕྲིཉོུ་ངེ་བྴོཡོདརིཆྟེཟ་ཡྴིལྡ༎ [vaviɾhagrusətiɾ sqa gəjaɽ͡r̥ ɖa ji musãʈəsĩɕakəɾĩɕmũtũjʁãgiŋʁãgharəzatvan ʐĩɖa bãn giɾtənbĩʐitahabraqũ ji tətɕumukhafəgir̥ mətɕanək] excellent+ADJ+inclusive POSS summit at AND woodlands+PL+acre+PL+50+ADJ+natural in BAN Girton+EXPL.SBJ+space+ADJ+think AND community+ADJ+thrive give Live in heritage buildings or state of the art accommodation, enjoy the Library, Cafe and indoor swimming pool, and some of the best on-site sporting and leisure facilities in the University.

docs.text: Original Script IPA Gloss A single shaft of light thrusts illumination into the main square, its brightness looking like a solid pillar in the heavy fog. གིུངམེརིཧྡོཡྶསཁི་ཀཕྲིུཝྠཡོུབཀེུབཡོུབྲིཆེཕྲརེུཆེཕྲ་ཙྙིཔྱ།ཁིུདསཉིཡིསཡེཕྲཀེུཅེགསིསརིཅེཚིལ་ཐེཝརིཟྲོཚིལ་ཙི་ཏྴོཡིཕ༎ [pãjzihaɹ̠əkumənsŋa brãʁəɕmũtbĩtmũt'afirhĩfir ɖəqadəm, ŋaksqamasmirbĩʈipsashaʈivan ɕiʁhaɽ͡r̥uvan ɖa gətɕumaɾ] plaza+ADJ+important+SUPER rod+PL+one+EXPL.SBJ+TOPIC+illumination+SBJ.ATTR+light thrust / 3SG+POSS+DEF+bright+EXPL.SBJ+pillar+ADJ+solid fog+ADJ+powerful in PASS+see I flipped your car with my super-strength because of your bad attitude. ཐེལ་སྙི་ཡྖིཆིཟྲོཀ་ཅིཡསཉིཟྲོཚིལརིཧོཧོ་སྲལོུ་ངེ་ཐེལསཉིཡདྲེཡེཟརིགྲི་སལོུཤི་ཏོུཆྙིཔྱ༎ [ɕin səqa mafafaɽ͡r̥ub ʈamsqaɽ͡r̥uvanhaɹ̠uɹ̠u ʂənũ ɕinsqamək'imir̥hap'a snũtɕa gũfəqadəm] 2SG POSS DEF-car-1SG.PST 1SG-POSS-power-ADJ-big-REDUP using 2SG-POSS-DEF-disposition-ADJ-bad cause flip-burst The child eats the big fish at home. ཡྤེཔེཀེུཡིཐཡེརིཧོ་ཁིདབེཧ་ཙི་ཙིདས༎ DEF-child-SBJ-DEF-fish-ADJ-big 3SG-home in eat

Some of the people shouted. Many of the people shouted twice. Happy people often shout.

docs.text: ཡམྲེཡརིངིཕྲམ མྲེཡསྲིབིུཔེརིངིཕྲམརེུཔེ་མྲབེཟ༎ཿཛིཁིུད་ཡོུ་རིུ་ཆྟོུང༎ཿཏཕོ་སྲིུསྲིཁིདསཉིཡིུཡིུ་ནོག༎ཿཛིཁིུད་ཡོུ་རིུ་ཆྟོུང༎ཿཏཕོ་སྲིུསྲིཁིདསཉིབིབིུ་ནོག༎ཚིུཧ།ཿཛིཁིུད་ཡོུ་རིུ་ཆྟོུང༎ཿཏཕོ་སྲིུསྲིཁིདསཉིབིུངིཁརེུགྷོས་ནོག༎ཉེསྠཟྲིད་གྲེ་ཡམྲེཡ་ཛེལཔ་ཡིདྫོཐསྲིཡྦིུཔེ་ཡིུམབྯིུཡི་ཚིུཧ་སྲིུརིཉྲིུང་ཡཟྲོུཀླ་ཨིུཡི༎ཆིམ་ཁིུདིས་ཡོུ་ཆྟོུང༎ཡླི་ཁིུདིས་ཡོུ་ཆྟོུང༎རིཡ་ཛིཁིུད་ཡོུ་རིུ་ཆྟོུང་སྲིུ་ནོགསྲིཧྦོཟྲད་བྲོུསྱ༎ཆིམ་ཉེསྠཟྲིད་གྲེ་ཉེསྠཟྲིད་གྲེ་ཁིད་ཛེལཔ་ཡིདྫོཐ་ཡིུམབྯིུཡི་ངེ་སྲིུརིཉྲིུང་ཡཟྲོུཀླ་ཨིུཡིསྲིས་བྲོུསྱ༎ཡླི།གྲོདརི་གྲེ་ངིཕྲམསྲི་ཆྟོུང་མྱེུཐ།རིཡ་ཛིཁིུད་རིུ་ངེཕ་སྲིུསྲིཡྦིུཔེརེུཔེ་གེསོུ༎ A little boy planted a carrot seed. His mother said, "I'm afraid it won't come up." His father said, "I'm afraid it won't come up." And his older brother said, "I'm afraid it won't come up." Every day the boy pulled up the weeds around the seed and sprinkled the ground with water. But nothing came up. And nothing came up. Everyone kept saying it wouldn't come up. And then, one day, a carrot came up just as the little boy had known it would.
